results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film is about family life in Geelong in the 1970s. Children Karen and Stuart have a ride on a motorbike, visits to the beach, to the ‘Bell Brae’ farm and to the snow, Karen’s 9th birthday party (filmed inside so quite dark), preparing for school, sports days and an extended family wedding. There are some great examples of 1970s fashion, particularly of the home made style.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 giving the children a ride on a motorcycle
00:00:20:00 family gathering sitting on the sand at the beach, eating ice creams
00:03:43:00 children surfing the waves
00:05:37:00 Karen’s nineth birthday party celebrations
00:05:55:00 the children riding their bikes around the house and the street, confident Karen waves to the camera
00:07:20:00 mother and daughter in the garden, Karen wearing ‘hotpants’ which were very popular in the 1970s
00:07:23:00 Karen poses for the camera in her ‘Brownies’ uniform
00:08:04:00 the grandparents of the family
00:08:58:00 Karen and Stuart ready for school
00:09:03:00 fishing off a pier
00:09:55:00 spectacular early 1970s hairstyles in preparation for one of the many family weddings
00:11:54:00 a family wedding in 1970s style
00:12:15:00 an extended family gathering
00:15:17:00 a visit to play in what might be sudden fall of snow
00:16:36:00 dad is wearing a 1970s ‘groovy’ outfit while posing with Karen and Stuart in the garden
00:17:07:00 Karen and companions do a ‘physical education’ display for the camera
00:17:57:00 Karen and Stuart pose with a blowup Santa in the garden
00:18:54:00 jet skiing at the beach

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film is a wonderful composite of the Nixon family’s life enjoying the company of their extended family at weddings, birthday gatherings and at the family holiday homes as well as on their travels to the Gold Coast, Queensland and Eildon Weir, Victoria. We see Karen turn six in the film as well as a great Christmas scene when both children are particularly excited to receive their presents, a watch for Karen and a scooter for Stuart.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 children on the beach at Portarlington
00:00:52:00 at a zoo
00:02:40:00 wedding with a tall headdress for the bride and bridesmaids in dark pink 1960s style dresses
00:04:10:00 Karen’s first day at school, in her uniform with school bag
00:04:24:00 Stuart on a trike (tricycle) saluting the camera
00:04:40:00 picnic on the beach with lots of extended family members
00:05:00:00 treasure hunt in the sand
00:06:54:00 the children on a farm tractor
00:07:20:00 the cousins of the family in a row at a driveway gate
00:08:19:00 Les, Karen and Stuart walking out of the water at the beach
00:09:49:00 children amusement park on ‘dodgem’ cars
00:11:26:00 Karen and Stuart being rowed in a rowboat, followed by a speedboat rushing past, very close to the shore
00:12:00:00 view of waterfront houses at the Gold Coast
00:12:10:00 TAA airplane taking off at an airport
00:13:27:00 extended family wedding with bridesmaids in what would have been (at the time) a very fashionable and wonderful burnt orange
00:15:28:00 Stuart receiving his Christmas scooter
00:16:00:00 Dorothy and daughter Karen in matching outfits
00:16:25:00 family members gathered under some shady trees at the beach
00:16:47:00 Karen very confidently ‘dinking’ her younger brother Stuart on his new scooter (by giving him a ride)
00:19:27:00 Dorothy and other women in the family laugh as they climb up, and fall on, a steep sand dune
00:20:13:00 Dorothy, Karen and Stuart stand outside their caravan at the beach
00:20:19:00 a family wedding, bridesmaids in purple and sporting some great examples of 1960s hairstyles
00:21:43:00 Karen’s sixth birthday party
00:22:27:00 Karen backstroking through the water
00:23:17:00 family picnic including a woman wearing a wonderful paisley shirt typical of fashion at the time
00:24:40:00 cooking on a vintage three-legged barbeque
00:26:00:00 a birthday party held at a holiday home possibly at Point Roadknight

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

In this film, the Nixon family are living in Alice Springs in 1966, until we see them returning to Victoria via a TAA flight. TAA (Trans Australian Airlines) was the major air service in the 1960s and 1970s flying to destinations all over Australian and its near neighbours of Papua New Guinea and Timor. One of the most memorable advertising jingles at the time was ‘Up, Up and away, with TAA, the Friendly, Friendly Way…’, a variation on the 1967 song Up, Up and Away, written by Jimmy Webb and also used by the US airline TWA.

At home in Herne Hill, new baby Stuart is introduced to the camera, in his ‘bassinette’, laughing at the camera, bouncing in a ‘bouncinette’, in his bath, in his ‘highchair’ and sitting on big sister Karen’s lap. The family spend time at the beach and Karen celebrates her fourth birthday.

Scenes of the Melbourne Zoo show the difference in standards for zoological practices between the 1960s and contemporary practices.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:23:00 view of houses in the arid setting of Alice Springs
00:01:15:00 mountain scenery seen across the scrubby desert
00:01:49:00 memorial for ‘Flynn of the Inland’
00:02:22:00 Dorothy wearing a very 1960s style ‘sunsuit’ for hot weather
00:02:30:00 children playing in a portable backyard swimming pool
00:03:16:00 views of rocks and a creek followed by Alice Springs township from a higher vantage point
00:04:50:00 (faint) carvings on a rock face
00:05:15:00 ‘John Flynn Church’
00:05:25:00 cars in Alice Springs
00:05:56:00 Karen wearing sunglasses
00:06:40:00 views around an Indigenous settlement
00:07:11:00 children eating watermelon
00:07:28:00 floods in the outback
00:07:45:00 TAA (Trans Australian Airlines) airplane on the tarmac at an outback airport
00:07:53:00 propeller of flying plane and views of the sea and land below, followed by landing scenes
00:08:51:00 scenes of baby Stuart at home in Herne Hill, Geelong
00:09:50:00 baby Stuart in a ‘bouncinette’ and in his ‘bassinette’
00:11:55:00 Les and Karen with baby Stuart
00:12:42:00 Dorothy in a Ford ‘Cortina’ model car
00:13:29:00 scenes at the beach
00:14:03:00 Karen and companion buried in the sand at the beach
00:15:48:00 scenes at the Melbourne Zoo
00:16:33:00 Karen’s fourth birthday celebrations
00:17:13:00 baby Stuart almost crawling across the carpet
00:18:08:00 Karen shows a popular activity of the time – the ‘hula hoop’
00:18:45:00 Stuart in a crate on the back of a bicycle
00:18:47:00 Karen shows off her ‘cowgirl’ outfit
00:19:17:00 baby Stuart walking
00:19:31:00 Karen and baby brother Stuart on a tricycle (trike)
00:21:00:00 baby Stuart walking with a toy lawn mower, on his tricycle and with Karen showing off a new outfit
00:21:37:00 at the beach and in the water
00:22:21:00 Dorothy and the children in new outfits in red and orange
00:23:06:00 late 1960s or early 1970s wedding
00:23:28:00 Les in 1970s style shorts and long socks
00:24:04:00 a ‘Victa’ brand lawn mower
00:25:30:00 garden scenes
00:25:40:00 a cricket game

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

In this film Les and Dorothy Nixon show off their first baby Karen (who features in the Nixon Collection until she is an adult herself) at their home in Herne Hill, Geelong, Victoria. There are also a few family weddings and visits and outings around Victoria.

These scenes are a lovely showcase of a baby’s first months, Karen’s first smiles, sitting up, being fed first ‘solids’, learning to crawl on the carpet, trying to open the kitchen cupboards and eventually walking. As well as these usual baby activities we see them in the context of the 1960s - style of clothes, carseat, bassinette, pram and playpen.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:25:00 infant Karen being carried around the family backyard by teenage girls, (possibly cousins in the large extended Corry-Nixon family)
00:01:02:00 family members climb a rock formation, followed by views of surrounding scenery
00:01:15:00 scenes of baby Karen’s christening or baptism day (assumed by the style of baby clothes and blanket and by Dorothy’s smart outfit which includes matching hat, gloves and necklace)
00:01:37:00 baby Karen being held by her grandmother and great aunt
00:01:47:00 baby Karen with father Len
00:02:19:00 baby Karen laughing in her bassinette
00:02:30:00 a family gathering for a beach picnic
00:04:11:00 extended family members gather for a photo with baby Karen
00:05:45:00 baby Karen being fed from a bowl, while she sits in her bassinette on the back porch of the home followed by a bath
00:06:54:00 a ‘dummy’ (pacifier or soother) hanging from above the bassinette
00:07:11:00 extended family members gather in front of one of their homes for a group scene; one of the women flits across the screen playfully swinging her skirt for the camera
00:08:00:00 baby Karen with Dorothy
00:08:57:00 a Holden model car from the era
00:10:20:00 baby Karen’s new car seat
00:11:21:00 an older baby Karen with a cousin in the backyard
00:12:09:00 a very 1960s style wedding
00:12:12:00 baby Karen chases an empty cigarette pack across the carpet floor, practising her crawling
00:13:57:00 baby Karen in her pram
00:14:46:00 Les mowing the lawn
00:15:08:00 first steps for Karen, with dad
00:15:30:00 at the beach, splashing around in the sea with cousins
00:16:25:00 family members paddle boarding and surfing
00:17:38:00 Karen wearing a sunbonnet in a ‘playpen’
00:18:46:00 Karen playing and laughing with dad
00:19:17:00 a lovely little rowboat named ‘Sea Wyf’
00:20:14:00 Karen crawling and first steps
00:21:40:00 Karen ‘frosting’ the window
00:21:56:00 a family picnic
00:24:01:00 women dressed in smart outfits including hats
00:24:09:00 1960s wedding in light blue
00:25:50:00 toddler Karen playing with bucket and spade at the beach
00:26:25:00 Karen and Les practise swimming with a board and family beach scenes
00:28:18:00 gladioli flowers in a vase, in the fashion of the day
00:30:43:00 public gardens

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection]
results.material_description:
5 x 400ft 9.5mm B&W silent home movies
7 x 8mm reels (4 x 100ft, 2 x 400ft)
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

Charles Edward Hayes was born on 28th March 1914 and grew up in Port Melbourne. In 1928 he joined Johns & Waygood in City Road, South Melbourne where he worked his way up from office boy to the machine shop becoming a fitter. In 1942 he was nominated to take charge of Johns & Waygood Munitions Annex in Montague making 10lb mortar bombs.

In the late 1940s, Charles purchased his first 9.5mm movie camera starting a hobby that would bring years of enjoyment. In November 1949 Charles purchased an Austin A40 car which he kept until 1973 – it also makes an appearance or two in the home movies! On the 11th November 1950, the family purchased a property at Miller Road, Heathmont, comprising 5 acres of land. They decided to build some sheds and try at being poultry farmers. Charles continued travelling to South Melbourne to work until 1956 when they became full time farmers.

Over the years the family had numerous cows, duck, pigs, sheep, dogs, cats and of course Ticka the cockatoo; all these animals were treated as pets. For socialising and fitness Charles with his wife Elsie, joined the local tennis club and enjoyed playing at the weekend. In 1958 Charles joined the Ringwood Movie Club through some friends and enjoyed the friendship of the club and continued to record their travels with his trusty home movie camera. In 1966 Charles went on to work for Nutritional Products in Mitcham, so they eased out of the poultry business.

Their daughter Olwyn married John Baker on the 9th July, 1967 and had two sons. Elenor married Ron Peach on 2nd April 1970 and had two daughters – Elenor kindly donated the films to ACMI. Elise and Charles were happily married more than 50 years, until he passed away in 1993. These films remain testament to a happy and hard-working family from Melbourne’s outer eastern suburbs.

This home movie collection was donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter, Elenor Peach.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows snippets of family life while at play, at birthday celebrations and on holiday. We see the family drive across the bridge to Phillip Island and enjoy swimming and canoeing at the beach there. The reel also includes scenes of caravan camping, koalas and a trip to the war memorial at Mount Macedon. The family enjoy games of tennis, ball games and swings and roundabouts at a playground. The film includes good examples of fashion, Austin cars and recreational activities of the time.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:01:37:00 children with their dad in the water at the beach (good example of bathing fashion)
00:02:58:00 tennis match between mum and dad
00:04:29:00 car with caravan and family in bush camp setting
00:05:14:00 Austin car with family standing at the front talking and combing hair
00:05:58:00 children being pushed on swings in a park by their mother (good fashion and sunglasses references)
00:7:30:00 close-up of little girl’s face as she blows out her birthday candles and looks to camera
00:07:41:00 family in front of war memorial at Mount Macedon
00:08:36:00 steam train travelling on a country rail line
00:08:46:00 family looking out from a ferry window
00:08:52:00 kids on a roundabout at a playground
00:09:00:00 grandmother, mother and children sitting on a playground wall – the grandmother is shooting a water pistol.
00:09:08:00 children on playground roundabout and dad jumps on to join them
00:09:32:00 a koala sitting in a tree climbs to the top and looks down
00:09:45:00 family and friends stand in front of a picket fence (good example of family groups and fashion from the time)
00:10:01:00 wide shot as cars travel across the bridge to Phillip Island

00:10:14:00 POV from inside car as it drives over the Phillip Island bridge

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 11]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows Sydney street, harbour and beach scenes and a family holiday to Tasmania and New Zealand. There are scenes of Bondi Beach, Taronga Zoo and wild animals in captivity showing a monkey riding a bicycle and performing tricks with a trainer. There are scenes on board and farewelling a passenger liner and passenger steam ferries in Sydney Harbour.

There are street scenes around Hobart, including Wrest Point Hotel, and a road trip to Mount Wellington, showing views along the way. The film shows New Zealand port towns and ports as well as a tourist boat trip on the fjords and scenery at Milford Sound. The family visits Rotorua and a recreation of a Maori Village depicting traditional Maori dance and dress performed for tourists. There are also scenes on a cruise ship of recreational activities.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows rural Victoria footage around Omeo. It features excavation of, and images of, the Kiewa Hydro Electric scheme including power station interiors and exteriors and dam footage. Also included are hobby farm images, of children and adults with calves and chickens and pet dogs and cats. There is footage of a man collecting cow manure from paddocks.

We see images of the Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show Grand Parade with goats, horses, Ayrshire and Illawarra cattle, jinkers, floats, horse-drawn carts with advertising. There is also footage of children playing childhood games on the family farm – wheelbarrow races, chasey, ball games and piggy-backs.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan):

00:00:01:00 children feeding chickens on farm
00:00:11:00 child sitting on cow and falling off as cow stands
00:00:30:00 family and friends with farm animals
00:00:48:00 man working on farm with shovel collecting cow manure
00:00:59:00 two children with kitten fighting over who gets to hold it
00:01:15:00 children playing chasing, running games around trees in rural setting
00:01:26:00 children with grandmother playing with skipping rope in rural setting (good family images and fashion example)
00:01:35:00 family on ship with crew working in background
00:02:11:00 Maroondah Dam plaque with reservoir details
00:02:46:00 men and children playing piggy back, wheelbarrow races, ball games on rural property (ood footage of childhood games and playing)
00:03:15:00 child and woman on farm with calves (good rural footage and fashion example)
00:05:11:00 Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show Grand Parade including Ayrshire and Illawara cattle and goats
00:05:17:00 Royal Melbourne Agricultural Show Grand Parade with Jinkers, horses and carts, floats and advertising carts
00:08:19:00 Carnation Milk factory interior and exterior
00:08:57:00 Mount Beauty postal address plaque
00:10:01:00 rural footage of Kiewa Hydroelectric scheme, including images of interior and exterior power station, electricity poles and dam
00:10:33:00 road sign with vintage car in background: road sign indicating Upper Kiewa Valley Road; Mt Beauty; Rocky Valley; Howmans Gap

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows family holidays and recreational activities including trips to the beach, road trips to regional Victoria, children’s playgrounds (including swings and slippery slides) farm animals, pets and women’s tennis.

There is footage of Melbourne during the 1956 Olympics, showing athletes warming up, relay track events, Flinders Street and St Paul’s Cathedral with Olympic decorations.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows the Hayes family on a holiday when they are young parents with their young daughters. The family travels to The Grampians (Gariwerd/Geriwerd), the coastal town of Warrnambool, and the Eildon Weir and Eildon Lake, all in Victoria, before heading to Sydney in New South Wales.

Scenes from a zoo at the time could be distressing to some viewers as contemporary zoological standards are very different to those of the early 1950s.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 children and their parents on board a carnival train ride and the young Hayes girls with enormous bows in their hair stand for the camera, one very unsure and one laughing
00:00:22:00 riding on top of an elephant and monkeys swinging in their cage, followed by goats, a glimpse of a hippopotamus, bears, swimming penguins and a pacing tiger
00:02:26:00 the young Hayes girls sit with their father on a bench
00:02:30:00 Mr and Mrs Hayes and one of the girls at a lookout over a mountain range, likely to be The Grampians (Gariwerd/Geriwerd) in Victoria
00:02:55:00 wandering along creeks and bush and near dramatic waterfalls
00:03:41:00 family members smile at the camera, some lovely sunglasses and one of the Hayes girls shows her tiny handbag to the camera
00:04:00:00 one of the children hand feeds a bottle of milk to a lamb before taking it for a walk on a lead followed by some horse riding lessons
00:04:52:00 a lovely country house set against the mountains in the immediate background and an array of 1940s to 1950s cars parked alongside
00:05:42:00 a sign ‘Silverband Falls’
00:06:07:00 hand feeding cows with food scraps
00:06:30:00 community races for children and adults
00:07:23:00 views of the Eildon Weir and boats on Lake Eildon
00:08:00:00 the girls sit on some used cable spools
00:08:23:00 a small candlelit memorial to King George VI
00:08:30:00 swimming in a pool while an airplane flies overhead
00:09:20:00 a large ferry and the Sydney Harbour Bridge from a distance and up-close followed by street scenes in Sydney
00:10:26:00 beachgoers on the sand, possibly at Manly in Sydney and a family and or friends gathering for the camera
00:11:10:00 views of Sydney’s older city buildings including the AWA building and tower (Amalgamated Wireless Australasia)
00:11:15:00 the koala enclosure at the zoo followed by more elephant rides
